heading: us: 'no tech disasters here'
subheading: the clinton administration's top y2k adviser says all is well as the calendar rollover approaches. "there will be no disasters," he says.
author: reuters
text: washington -- with only three days remaining before the year 2000 rollover, president clinton's top y2k adviser said on tuesday he expects no national or regional disasters resulting from computer malfunctions. speaking in a television interview, white house y2k troubleshooter john koskinen said "we're very confident there will be no disasters" linked to us infrastructure, like the electric power or telecommunications sectors."[problems] will not rise to anything significant on a national basis," koskinen said.minor computer glitches, however, will likely occur, as they do everyday across the country, but koskinen said americans would likely not notice anything abnormal this weekend.he said some people may experience delayed dial tones when making phone calls and slower bill processing.koskinen chairs the president's council on year 2000 conversion.of concern are possible failures or malfunctions of automated computer systems that, if left uncorrected, may confuse 2000 with 1900 because of an old practice of using two digits to designate the year.koskinen was not asked about reports seattle has cancelled its new year's eve celebration at the famed space needle for security reasons. he did reiterate that people should be prepared for a long, mid-winter weekend, and not be overly worried. "there is no reason to disrupt the normal patterns of life."the united states has tightened security ahead of the new year at airports and border crossings since the arrest two weeks ago of an algerian man accused of trying to smuggle explosives into washington state from vancouver.copyright* 1999 reuters limited.*
